title: Grade 12 - Career and Work Exploration B30 (2022)
subject: Practical and Applied Arts

document.title: Grade 12 - Career and Work Exploration B30 (2022)

2C722BDB2A634902B0DF4CBAAC232E48.description: Develop and/or revise personal and career goals based on the work placement experience.

8639FC9C490B448A840F2305DD254CC5.description: In appreciation prepare a letter, note, card or other communication for the work placement employer.

6E17CD81DF6E4AFBB63542E3801FA348.description: Update artifacts (e.g., resume and evidences of learning) within one’s career portfolio following the work placement

6BA66352F21A40C0874B05FD1188CECD.description: Summarize the work placement experience by considering things such as: interactions with the employer, staff, customers and others; personal accomplishments; learnings about oneself; learnings about the world of work; learnings about careers in the workplace; and, personal demonstration of skills, abilities and understandings.

E3E375FF43E74E2D9AB1B71BAAE29D9B.description: Showcase one’s skills and abilities demonstrated during the work placement using artifacts, evidence of skill development and personal reflections on aspects of the work experience such as: hours worked; responsibilities and tasks performed; the importance of attitude towards work and taking responsibility for what needs to be done; details about the entry level wage, salary scales and earning potential; worker rights and responsibilities and the role of the union, if applicable; the presence of workplace hazards and how they were addressed; ownership structure (e.g., corporation, franchise, sole proprietorship and partnership); and, opportunities for advancement at the workplace and elsewhere in the industry.

88C0A2B8ADD2426387DF5712F535C0E8.description: Relate one’s work placement experience to personal and career goals.

7B4905ACFFDF427DA9F39CD8FAF94FDF.description: Document observations of employment standards, workplace ethics, privacy, culture, rights and responsibilities, occupational health and safety, and networking during the work placement.

1728132BFC994F1F8E7BF6DBDCA74BD6.description: Document one’s experience using electronic and other tools such as vlogs, blogs, log sheets and reflective journals to summarize and reflect on items such as: hours of work including breaks; responsibilities and tasks performed; worker rights and responsibilities and the role of the union, if applicable; interactions with the employer, staff, customers and others; company or organization’s ‘raison d’être’; and, transferable skills developed and demonstrated during the work placement that enhance ones’ employability

4333BC3029444129ABEFCD4446441DAF.description: Apply relevant skills and abilities during the work placement experience.

BA992672A20540A6A14987F981FF46F5.description: Participate in a work placement experience.

16CA95F0F860453A9DCA1777902171B0.description: Reflect on one’s performance during the interview.

6361F1C5C862450897AC9A7F7DDFC3C2.description: Participate in an interview with the employer prior to beginning the work placement.

407FD1699E644E718260886211050207.description: Develop a list of questions that might be asked by the employer in the preplacement interview and prepare answers for them.

0EDCB0E4B4EF4D65AD28624C73932575.description: Brainstorm a list of questions to ask the employer before beginning the work placement; these may include: What is my schedule of work hours? Who is my supervisor? What should I wear? What personal grooming standards are expected? When will I be provided with safety training?

115E4B9A640A41F9B2F13B34EA9B0F3B.description: Describe how factors such as one’s educational and other experiences including paid, unpaid and volunteer work; self-concept; personality; needs; values; interests; knowledge; skills; attitudes; and career goals and plan might impact one’s contribution in the workplace.

89FB1788CF644D4E8B4BE82344B8DBBD.description: Compile an employer information package that includes documents (e.g., permission forms, logs and self- and employer- evaluation forms) needed for the work placement

78ACB6EEB696456A91A9D1EF79025383.description: Develop a procedural guide for the work placement that includes items such as: transportation to and from the work placement; hours of work; • guidelines for absence and tardiness; dress code; job description; and, conflict resolution.

27AD0FBFB8DC47A7B9DE42C6E1BF4EA7.description: Update personal career artifacts (e.g., resume and cover letter) as required for the work placement, and provide to the work placement employer.

EC2B699F67204D4EA7242F4627AFCAE8.description: Prepare for the work placement experience.

1026C441D27C4849A38AE846EC81CB5E.description: Develop personal and learning goals for the work placement in consultation with the parent or guardian, teacher or other school staff member and employer.

2D84C066F410416E9A3D11607B99BC7F.description: Reflect on one’s right to know, right to participate and right to refuse while in the work placement.

CF5A3C85EDC74DB4AD51563640AD1B01.description: Identify employment standards (e.g., use of a uniform) that may pertain to one’s work placement.

5BE173D8DFAC477AA170B58C28DA1626.description: Compose a list of questions related to workplace hazards and safety to ask of the work placement employer such as: • What physical, chemical, ergonomic or biological hazards should I be aware of in my work placement?, When will I receive job safety training and orientation before I begin work?,  Where do I find fire extinguishers, first aid kits and emergency assistance?, What type of safety gear or other clothing am I expected to wear? Is it provided?, What should I do if I get injured or have an accident in the workplace?,  How can I contact my health and safety committee or representative?, Are there any health and safety procedures I should follow?, Who is the first aid person? • Where are safety notices posted? • What should I do in case of a fire or emergency?

1579C710CF2E4340B8FBA9AF1843E04E.description: Identify safety hazards that could potentially be encountered during the work placement experience

A8C6E8CC95DF41DE820A55F1FA7F1CA6.description: Role-play scenarios that may be encountered during the work placement such as: providing customer/client service; collaborating with colleagues; dealing with a disagreement; and, expressing one’s perspective or opinion on a matter.

59A184CAC3DA43B188DE683D54350DC9.description: Research the business/organization to become familiar with its operations.

1B89C251E8754B4EACEFD75C7F8F5B41.description: Explain the roles and responsibilities of each partner (e.g., student, parent or guardian, teacher or other school staff and employer) involved in the work placement.

42F74C615C3A4E41B0D6796FCBEEFEE7.description: Explore factors that contribute to a successful work placement experience.

5C6DEA50D3D94763915326ACFF0B165E.description: Research employee and employer rights and responsibilities that foster a culture of privacy in the workplace.

ED4DC82A8E6E457F9E9DA284544FBD04.description: Compare employers’ and employees’ expectations with respect to fair and ethical workplace practices.

43348EBCDA0F4982B8C8E6BE59E584AE.description: Compare the code of ethics for school with a code of ethics for a workplace.

5D590246A8D042838ABD28D91CCDBC39.description: Discuss ways to deal with harassment of self or others in the workplace.

BEAEFCAEA64E4BD6BCAD42088099CE13.description: Investigate the term harassment and discuss the potential effects of harassment on mental health and wellbeing.

B20AD4E04AB542749A43E8AADDC556BF.description: Discuss advantages and disadvantages of being employed in a workplace where workers are unionized.

37B56A19906A41C9BDA0C61DE643BFC6.description: Discuss common expectations for union members in the workplace.

037E58F6F5EB4786AD6BC2862EC47A46.description: Investigate the role of unions in the workplace.

D054034A561C492286EE24FC52DE238D.description: Research the evolution of unions in Saskatchewan and Canada.

363A66CF9C324B428DB09DF33BBA0401.description: Discuss the impact of ethical (e.g., responsibility, honesty and confidentiality) and unethical (e.g., conflict of interest, abuse of substances, sexual harassment, bullying, theft, falsifying documents and reports, and misrepresentation) behaviours on the workplace.

D7E8DDB1ABFC42649BD9589181F1546C.description: Examine fair and ethical practices and privacy rights in the workplace.

FB0C246504EE43D08B622B2428163654.description: Research sources of support (e.g., Human Resources Department, union, Saskatchewan Health Authority, Canadian Mental Health Association, Mental Health Commission of Canada and Canadian Centre for Occupational Health and Safety) for those experiencing mental health problems or issues in the workplace.

BC904D304D514A3B80F5E658161D9B75.description: Discuss barriers (e.g., lack of awareness that accommodations may be possible, lack of awareness of where to find supports and lack of confidence in requesting accommodations) that employees face in disclosing a mental health problem or illness and/or in requesting accommodations

F1DE59A40BBC4ACC894F469C5DC10A5D.description: Research employers’ ‘duty to accommodate’ as outlined in the Canadian Human Rights Code.

FF78F3FEB9D049538F36332E8FD27A40.description: Research accommodations (e.g., modification of work duties, flexible hours, job sharing and modifications to the work environment) that employees experiencing mental health problems or issues can request.

B37634B43B0C4E92A938F97D661E5258.description: Research employers’ duties and responsibilities about workplace mental health as outlined in The Saskatchewan Employment Act, 2019.

8CB4ED4CF9C04E02ACAC206AFC1DDF74.description: Describe practical ways that employees can contribute to a psychologically healthy and safe workplace.

4AA189A8BB4C4C0DA28433B62DC649DB.description: Research employers’ responsibility for establishing a psychologically healthy and safe workplace.

4B7AA1A837194C288E07038833DFE5BB.description: Discuss the benefits of a psychologically healthy and safe workplace to employees and employers.

C8F8D0C584D94FEDA0667ADA7C6EE53E.description: Research how areas of stress, including personal financial stress, impact productivity in the workplace.

D07C1D1A1EE34301A0867D9D73B9D7C7.description: Research the prevalence of mental illness in Canada and the resulting impact on the workplace

C3CE720BF55B4D4AA02BD83D5E45EADF.description: Define life/work balance and how it relates to maintaining personal wellness.

B9C84BFDD4454B9BA1ECB1EE63F854FF.description: Explore psychological health and safety in the workplace.

9AD53378DC234A8BA521342278D088C0.description: Workplace Safety – Psychological Health and Safety (Core)

4418F9B0B1904BB3B81BD1B6985009DA.description: Role-play a variety of scenarios that require one to evaluate hazardous materials and respond appropriately.

8E6E6AEA9F544C8B95F2881E785762C9.description: Describe the usefulness of Safety Data Sheets (SDS) in helping to control hazardous materials.

D3E51789A3AA46CF8503911F2172FB08.description: Identify the 16 sections of a Safety Data Sheet (SDS).

976571B908BD452EB5ACBF1BFF0C4064.description: Describe the purpose and contents of current hazard pictograms.

0A1F334D25F34505A836C852E0A9000D.description: Differentiate between the supplier label and workplace label.

CCD5CDBADBB942DEA6928B4D61E21EA7.description: Describe the two main types of WHMIS 2015 labels (i.e., supplier and workplace).

C275B64E88D24787825D66D8F3F1D316.description: Identify the roles and responsibilities of the employer, worker, and supplier in relation to the safe handling of hazardous materials.

DB3A07E3974341B0A0A3D38A106E8154.description: Define the four parts of WHMIS 2015 (i.e., hazard identification and product classification; labels with warning symbols; Safety Data Sheets (SDS); and worker education and worksite specific training) that help workers handle hazardous materials safely.

1C1F81BA28244E4A96D6352147C33E0A.description: Describe the hierarchy of controls that is standard practice in the workplace for minimizing and eliminating exposure to hazards, including: Elimination (i.e., physically removing the hazard); Substitution (i.e., replacing the hazard); Engineering controls (i.e., isolating people from the hazard); Administrative controls (i.e., changing the way work is performed); and, Personal Protective Equipment (i.e., protecting the worker with Personal Protective Equipment).

24BE2C07AA9E41AC9645617EB5C7B1C7.description: Discuss factors that determine the required level of workplace specific training in WHMIS 2015.

D92D705EA7574F8684B6B85484F938FE.description: Differentiate between general education and workplace training in regards to WHMIS 2015.

E5402388EAA346399375A1FC994F382A.description: Discuss what the Workplace Hazardous Materials Information System (WHMIS) is and its purpose and scope in the workplace.

954E2314804D4EDABFECEB573DAC1FC1.description: Explore the Workplace Hazardous Materials Information System (WHMIS).

A9B78895755843DEB0E0F6A99A3039F0.description: Workplace Safety – Workplace Hazardous Materials Information System (WHMIS)

A2A17ECCFEDD48A99D2FCE26E826BED7.description: Discuss the need for health and safety legislation and regulations.

7810A1E4372E45BA91D313CC074868A7.description: Identify employer responsibilities in relation to safety hazards.

8A25D3287CA143FE9C89544270423662.description: Explain health and safety regulations common to a specific occupation of interest.

55719CCCD4844603BBDF95FD69AFEA3C.description: Describe current prevention programs or agencies (e.g., Mission Zero, Work Safe Saskatchewan and Saskatchewan Safety Council) in Saskatchewan that are designed to raise awareness of and prevent workplace incidents.

4D28E549DE63421F8D3D2237D68DDDCC.description: Explore safety statistics related to young workers in the workplace in Saskatchewan and Canada and compare the statistics to those of workers in other age brackets.

E4627275D94043DF95EBBDC222D85A05.description: Identify potential safety hazards in a variety of environments including home, school, and workplace.

9A18F1D3D88E4EDE87A74CCA5D136D8C.description: Discuss the importance of proper orientation, training, appropriate supervision, workplace inspections and following safe work practices, and provide examples of each for a variety of industries.

92655CCAD3804935809E263FD23B3035.description: Describe employers’ and employees’ rights and responsibilities pertaining to workplace hazards and how they can work together to prevent workplace hazards.

FD03322FDAB8476183402E3F1D9C2901.description: Provide examples of potential workplace hazards in the five major categories.

5C4D6DC74437485093FCA6F1886243E3.description: Differentiate among the four Occupational Health and Safety (OHS) hazard categories including physical (e.g., heavy lifting, repetitive motion, slipping/tripping, working at heights, working alone, cuts and burns), chemical (e.g., chemicals, fumes, vapours and gases), biological (e.g., viruses, fungi, bacteria, mold; bodily fluids; sewage; animal/pet waste; and influenza), and psychological (e.g., harassment and bullying, stress, fatigue and shift work).

A6CA8C84D4024F10A682C6FB583CCA4C.description: Differentiate between a workplace hazard and risk.

964D1CADC70B460B898D78695A2B1F3C.description: Discuss how a workplace injury might affect the injured worker and others such as the employer, supervisor, work colleagues, family and friends.

51AD67866F01454D8972D4384464ECF3.description: Explore workplace hazards and injury prevention.

E59ECD8F5D1F4D4E891C4F46F886B028.description: Workplace Safety – Hazards and Injury Prevention (Core)

3B034C4102B74D2B926A74F368DE985A.description: Discuss the importance of reporting workplace incidents, dangerous occurrences, injuries, or illnesses immediately and the proper procedure to do so.

2AF9CAAE238245F990252A9363B77B89.description: Investigate how workers can participate in and support health and safety activities in the workplace. (e.g., Occupational Health and Safety Committees, professional development, training and following safety procedures).

8D6B9014DB6E404DAA545475100CDEC2.description: Explain the purpose of The Saskatchewan Employment Act, 2019 and associated Regulations, and how they affect safe workplace practices

F22A03B2BEEE406F822935C58859881A.description: Role-play scenarios to demonstrate how to properly refuse potentially unsafe work.

135003F01E924729A25AD3CA936B013B.description: Discuss steps that can be taken to refuse potentially unsafe work.

55152C0BC19C4DBBB22B6ACD779C18C7.description: Research employer and worker responsibilities with respect to health and safety standards as required by law in Saskatchewan.

011FD1F4BC674398A6B6A00930622375.description: Describe and reflect on the three basic rights that all workers have under Part III – Occupational Health and Safety in The Saskatchewan Employment Act, 2019: the right to know - the hazards at work and how to control them; the right to participate - in finding and controlling workplace hazards; and, the right to refuse - work that you believe is unusually dangerous.

9FBA5CBF354443CE862366457D3A3735.description: Analyze the importance of rights and responsibilities in relation to workplace safety.
